title: J-pop
text:
J-pop (, "jeipoppu"; often stylized as J-POP; an abbreviated form of "Japanese popular music"), natively also known simply as , is a musical genre that entered the musical mainstream of <a href="Japan">Japan</a> in the 1990s. Modern J-pop has its roots in traditional Japanese music, but significantly in <a href="1960s%20in%20music">1960s</a> <a href="pop%20music">pop</a> and <a href="rock%20music">rock music</a>, such as <a href="The%20Beatles">The Beatles</a> and <a href="The%20Beach%20Boys">The Beach Boys</a>, which led to <a href="Japanese%20rock">Japanese rock</a> bands such as <a href="Happy%20End%20%28band%29">Happy End</a> fusing rock with <a href="Music%20of%20Japan">Japanese music</a> in the early 1970s. J-pop was further defined by <a href="New%20wave%20music">new wave</a> and <a href="Crossover%20music">crossover</a> <a href="Jazz%20fusion">fusion</a> acts of the late 1970s such as <a href="Yellow%20Magic%20Orchestra">Yellow Magic Orchestra</a> and <a href="Southern%20All%20Stars">Southern All Stars</a>, then <a href="Eurobeat">Eurobeat</a> in the early 1990s, namely <a href="Namie%20Amuro">Namie Amuro</a>.
Eventually, J-pop replaced "<a href="kay%C5%8Dkyoku">kayōkyoku</a>" ("Lyric Singing Music", a term for Japanese popular music from the 1920s to the 1980s) in the Japanese music scene. The term was coined by the Japanese media to distinguish Japanese music from foreign music and now refers to most Japanese popular music. Popular styles of Japanese <a href="pop%20music">pop music</a> included <a href="technopop">technopop</a> during the 1970s1980s, <a href="city%20pop">city pop</a> in the 1980s, and <a href="Shibuya-kei">Shibuya-kei</a> in the 1990s.
Form and definition.
The origin of modern J-pop is said to be Japanese-language <a href="rock%20music">rock music</a> inspired by the likes of <a href="The%20Beatles">The Beatles</a>. Unlike the Japanese music genre called "<a href="kay%C5%8Dkyoku">kayōkyoku</a>", J-pop uses a special kind of pronunciation, which is similar to that of <a href="English%20language">English</a>. One notable singer to do so is <a href="Keisuke%20Kuwata">Keisuke Kuwata</a>, who pronounced the Japanese word "karada" ("body") as "kyerada". Additionally, unlike Western music, the <a href="major%20second">major second</a> ("sol" and "la") was usually not used in Japanese music, except <a href="art%20music">art music</a>, before rock music became popular in Japan. When the <a href="Group%20Sounds">Group Sounds</a> genre, which was inspired by Western rock, became popular, Japanese pop music adopted the major second, which was used in the final sounds of The Beatles' song "<a href="I%20Want%20to%20Hold%20Your%20Hand">I Want to Hold Your Hand</a>" and <a href="The%20Rolling%20Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>' song "<a href="%28I%20Can%27t%20Get%20No%29%20Satisfaction">(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction</a>". Although Japanese pop music changed from music based on Japanese <a href="pentatonic%20scale">pentatonic scale</a> and distortional <a href="tetrachord">tetrachord</a> to the more occidental music over time, music that drew from the traditional Japanese singing style remained popular (such as that of <a href="Ringo%20Shiina">Ringo Shiina</a>).
At first, the term "J-pop" was used only for Western-style musicians in Japan, such as <a href="Pizzicato%20Five">Pizzicato Five</a> and <a href="Flipper%27s%20Guitar">Flipper's Guitar</a>, just after Japanese radio station <a href="J-Wave">J-Wave</a> was established. On the other hand, Mitsuhiro Hidaka of <a href="AAA%20%28band%29">AAA</a> from <a href="Avex%20Trax">Avex Trax</a> said that J-pop was originally derived from the <a href="Eurobeat">Eurobeat</a> genre. However, the term became a <a href="blanket%20term">blanket term</a>, covering other music genres—such as the majority of Japanese rock music of the 1990s.
In 1990, the Japanese subsidiary of <a href="Tower%20Records%20%28music%20retailer%29">Tower Records</a> defined J-pop as all Japanese music belonging to the <a href="Recording%20Industry%20Association%20of%20Japan">Recording Industry Association of Japan</a> except Japanese <a href="independent%20music">independent music</a> (which they term "J-indie"); their stores began to use additional classifications, such as J-club, J-punk, <a href="Japanese%20hip%20hop">J-hip-hop</a>, <a href="Japanese%20reggae">J-reggae</a>, <a href="Music%20in%20Japanese%20animation">J-anime</a>, and <a href="Visual%20kei">Visual kei</a> by 2008, after independent musicians started to release works via major labels. Ito Music City, a Japanese record store, adopted expanded classifications including Group Sounds, <a href="Japanese%20idol">idol</a> of the 1970s–1980s, <a href="enka">enka</a>, <a href="folk%20music">folk</a> and established musicians of the 1970s–1980s, in addition to the main J-pop genres.
Whereas rock musicians in Japan usually hate the term "pop", Taro Kato, a member of <a href="pop%20punk">pop punk</a> band <a href="Beat%20Crusaders">Beat Crusaders</a>, pointed out that the encoded <a href="pop%20music">pop music</a>, like <a href="pop%20art">pop art</a>, was catchier than "J-pop" and he also said that J-pop was the music, memorable for its frequency of airplay, in an interview when the band completed their first full-length studio album under a major label, "", in 2005. Because the band did not want to perform J-pop music, their album featured the <a href="1980s%20in%20music%23Pop">1980s Pop</a> of <a href="MTV">MTV</a>. According to his fellow band member Toru Hidaka, the 1990s music that influenced him (such as <a href="Nirvana%20%28band%29">Nirvana</a>, <a href="Hi-Standard">Hi-Standard</a>, and <a href="Flipper%27s%20Guitar">Flipper's Guitar</a>) was not listened to by fans of other music in Japan at that time.
In contrast to this, although many Japanese rock musicians until the late 1980s disrespected the "<a href="kay%C5%8Dkyoku">kayōkyoku</a>" music, many of Japanese rock bands of the 1990s—such as <a href="Glay">Glay</a>—assimilated "kayōkyoku" into their music. After the late 1980s, <a href="breakbeat">breakbeat</a> and <a href="sampler%20%28musical%20instrument%29">sampler</a>s also changed the Japanese music scene, where expert <a href="drummer">drummer</a>s had played good rhythm because <a href="traditional%20Japanese%20music">traditional Japanese music</a> did not have the rhythm based on rock or blues.
Hide of <a href="Greeeen">Greeeen</a> openly described their music genre as J-pop. He said, "I also love rock, hip hop and breakbeats, but my field is consistently J-pop. For example, hip hop musicians learn 'the culture of hip hop' when they begin their career. We are not like those musicians and we love the music as sounds very much. Those professional people may say 'What are you doing?' but I think that our musical style is cool after all. The good thing is good."
History.
1920s–1960s: Ryūkōka.
Japanese popular music, called "<a href="ry%C5%ABk%C5%8Dka">ryūkōka</a>" before being split into "<a href="enka">enka</a>" and "poppusu",
has origins in the <a href="Meiji%20period">Meiji period</a>, but most Japanese scholars consider the <a href="Taish%C5%8D%20period">Taishō period</a> to be the actual starting point of "ryūkōka", as it is the era in which the genre first gained nationwide popularity. By the Taishō period, Western musical techniques and instruments, which had been <a href="Foreign%20relations%20of%20Meiji%20Japan">introduced to Japan in the Meiji period</a>, were widely used. Influenced by Western genres such as <a href="Jazz%20music">jazz</a> and <a href="blues">blues</a>, "ryūkōka" incorporated Western instruments such as the <a href="violin">violin</a>, <a href="harmonica">harmonica</a>, and <a href="guitar">guitar</a>. However, the melodies were often written according to the traditional Japanese <a href="pentatonic%20scale">pentatonic scale</a>. In the 1930s, <a href="Ichiro%20Fujiyama">Ichiro Fujiyama</a> released popular songs with his <a href="tenor">tenor</a> voice. Fujiyama sang songs with a lower volume than <a href="opera">opera</a> through the <a href="microphone">microphone</a> (the technique is sometimes called "<a href="Crooner">crooning</a>").
Jazz musician <a href="Ryoichi%20Hattori">Ryoichi Hattori</a> attempted to produce Japanese native music which had a "flavor" of <a href="blues">blues</a>.
He composed <a href="Noriko%20Awaya">Noriko Awaya</a>'s hit song "Wakare no Blues" (lit. "Farewell Blues"). Awaya became a famous popular singer and was called "Queen of Blues" in Japan. Due to pressure from the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Army">Imperial Army</a> during the war, the performance of jazz music was temporarily halted in Japan. Hattori, who stayed in <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a> at the end of the war, produced hit songs such as <a href="Shizuko%20Kasagi">Shizuko Kasagi</a>'s "Tokyo Boogie-Woogie" and <a href="Ichiro%20Fujiyama">Ichiro Fujiyama</a>'s "Aoi Sanmyaku" (lit. "Blue Mountain Range"). Hattori later became known as the "Father of Japanese "poppusu"". The <a href="United%20States">United States</a> soldiers—who were <a href="occupation%20of%20Japan">occupying Japan</a> at the time—and the <a href="Far%20East%20Network">Far East Network</a> introduced a number of new musical styles to the country. <a href="Boogie-woogie">Boogie-woogie</a>, <a href="Mambo%20%28music%29">Mambo</a>, <a href="Blues">Blues</a>, and <a href="Country%20music">Country music</a> were performed by Japanese musicians for the American troops. <a href="Chiemi%20Eri">Chiemi Eri</a>'s cover song "<a href="Tennessee%20Waltz">Tennessee Waltz</a>" (1952), <a href="Hibari%20Misora">Hibari Misora</a>'s "Omatsuri Mambo" (1952), and <a href="Izumi%20Yukimura">Izumi Yukimura</a>'s cover song "<a href="Till%20I%20Waltz%20Again%20with%20You">Till I Waltz Again with You</a>" (1953) also became popular. Foreign musicians and groups, including <a href="JATP">JATP</a> and <a href="Louis%20Armstrong">Louis Armstrong</a>, visited Japan to perform. In the mid-1950s, became a popular venue for live jazz music. Jazz had a large impact on Japanese "poppusu", though "authentic" jazz did not become the mainstream genre of music in Japan. In the late 1950s and early 1960s, Japanese pop was polarized between urban "<a href="kay%C5%8Dkyoku">kayō</a>" and modern "enka".
Modern J-pop is also sometimes believed to have had its roots with <a href="Shidaiqu">Chinese immigrant jazz musicians</a> who had fled <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a> during the <a href="Chinese%20Civil%20War">communist takeover</a>, and were collaborating with the <a href="Occupation%20of%20Japan">U.S.-occupied forces</a> to help introduce s variety of new genres to the Japanese public. In 1949, when the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20China">communists</a> took over and established the <a href="China">People's Republic of China</a> on the <a href="Mainland%20China">mainland</a>, one of the first actions taken by the <a href="Politics%20of%20China">government</a> was to denounce popular music (specifically both Chinese pop music, known as <a href="Mandopop">Mandopop</a>, and Western pop music) as <a href="Yellow%20Music">decadent music</a>, and for decades afterwards the Communist Party would promote <a href="Political%20music%20in%20China%23Birth%20of%20Revolutionary%20songs%20%281949-1970s%29">Chinese revolutionary songs</a> while suppressing Chinese folk songs, Chinese pop songs and Western pop songs. Dissatisfied with <a href="Chairman%20of%20the%20Communist%20Party%20of%20China">Chairman</a> <a href="Mao%20Zedong">Mao Zedong</a>'s new music policies, a number of Shanghainese jazz musicians fled to the <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> colony of <a href="British%20Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> and established <a href="Cantopop">Cantopop</a>, which is pop music sung in the <a href="Cantonese">Cantonese</a> dialect of <a href="Chinese%20language">Chinese</a>. However, a few musicians instead settled in Japan, where they became members of the <a href="Far%20East%20Network">Far East Network</a> and collaborated with the <a href="United%20States%20Army">American soldiers</a> to help expose the Japanese public to a wide variety of western genres. This eventually lead to the establishment of modern Japanese pop music, known as "<a href="kay%C5%8Dkyoku">kayōkyoku</a>".
1960s: Origin of modern style.
Rokabirī Boom and Wasei pops.
During the 1950s and 60s, many Kayōkyoku groups and singers gained experience performing on US military bases in Japan. Around the same time, <a href="Yakuza">Yakuza</a> manager <a href="Kazuo%20Taoka">Kazuo Taoka</a> reorganized the concert touring industry by treating the performers as professionals. Many of these performers later became key participants in the J-pop genre.
In 1956, Japan's <a href="rock%20and%20roll">rock and roll</a> craze began, due to the country music group known as Kosaka Kazuya and the Wagon Masters; their rendition of <a href="Elvis%20Presley">Elvis Presley</a>'s song "<a href="Heartbreak%20Hotel">Heartbreak Hotel</a>" helped to fuel the trend. The music was called "<a href="rockabilly">rockabilly</a>" (or "rokabirī") by the Japanese media. Performers learned to play the music and translate the lyrics of popular American songs, resulting in the birth of . The rockabilly movement would reach its peak when 45,000 people saw the performances by Japanese singers at the first Nichigeki Western Carnival in one week of February 1958.
<a href="Kyu%20Sakamoto">Kyu Sakamoto</a>, a fan of Elvis, made his stage début as a member of the band <a href="The%20Drifters%20%28Japanese%20band%29">The Drifters</a> at the Nichigeki Western Carnival in 1958. His 1961 song "Ue wo Muite Arukō" ("Let's Look Up and Walk"), known in other parts of the world as "<a href="Sukiyaki%20%28song%29">Sukiyaki</a>", was released to the United States in 1963. It was the first Japanese song to reach the Number One position in the United States, spending four weeks in "<a href="Cash%20Box">Cash Box</a>" and three weeks in "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>". It also received a <a href="Music%20recording%20sales%20certification">gold record</a> for selling one million copies. During this period, female duo <a href="The%20Peanuts">The Peanuts</a> also became popular, singing a song in the movie "<a href="Mothra%20%28film%29">Mothra</a>". Their songs, such as "Furimukanaide" ("Don't Turn Around") were later covered by <a href="Candies%20%28group%29">Candies</a> on their album "Candy Label". Artists like Kyu Sakamoto and The Peanuts were called .
After frequently changing members, <a href="Chosuke%20Ikariya">Chosuke Ikariya</a> re-formed The Drifters in 1964 under the same name. At a Beatles concert in 1966, they acted as curtain raisers, but the audience generally objected. Eventually, The Drifters became popular in Japan, releasing "Zundoko-Bushi" ("Echoic word tune") in 1969. Along with "enka" singer <a href="Keiko%20Fuji">Keiko Fuji</a>, they won "the award for mass popularity" at the <a href="12th%20Japan%20Record%20Awards">12th Japan Record Awards</a> in 1970. Keiko Fuji's 1970 album "Shinjuku no Onna/'Enka no Hoshi' Fuji Keiko no Subete" ("Woman in Shinjuku/'Star of "Enka" All of Keiko Fuji") established an all-time record in the history of the Japanese <a href="Oricon">Oricon</a> chart by staying in the Number One spot for 20 consecutive weeks. The Drifters later came to be known as television personalities and invited <a href="Japanese%20idol">idols</a> such as <a href="Momoe%20Yamaguchi">Momoe Yamaguchi</a> and Candies to their television program.
Ereki boom and group sounds.
<a href="The%20Ventures">The Ventures</a> visited Japan in 1962, causing the widespread embrace of the <a href="electric%20guitar">electric guitar</a> called the ""Ereki" boom". <a href="Y%C5%ABz%C5%8D%20Kayama">Yūzō Kayama</a> and <a href="Takeshi%20Terauchi">Takeshi Terauchi</a> became famous players of electric guitar. In 1966, <a href="the%20Beatles">the Beatles</a> came to Japan and sang their songs at the <a href="Nippon%20Budokan">Nippon Budokan</a>, becoming the first <a href="rock%20music">rock music</a> band to perform a concert there. The public believed that the Beatles would cause <a href="juvenile%20delinquency">juvenile delinquency</a>. The Japanese government deployed <a href="riot%20police">riot police</a> against young rock fans at the Nippon Budokan. <a href="John%20Lennon">John Lennon</a> felt that they were not well regarded in Japan, but <a href="Beatlemania">Beatlemania</a> has never really died there. The Beatles inspired Japanese bands, creating the <a href="group%20sounds">group sounds</a> genre in Japan.
Most Japanese musicians felt that they could not sing rock in <a href="Japanese%20language">Japanese</a>, so the popularity of Japanese rock gradually declined. As a result, there were debates such as "Should we sing rock music in Japanese?" and "Should we sing in English?" between <a href="Happy%20End%20%28band%29">Happy End</a> and <a href="Y%C5%ABya%20Uchida%20%28singer/actor%29">Yuya Uchida</a> about Japanese rock music. This confrontation was called . Happy End proved that rock music could be sung in Japanese, and one theory holds that their music became one of the origins of modern J-pop. The Beatles also inspired <a href="Eikichi%20Yazawa">Eikichi Yazawa</a>, who grew up in an underprivileged family, his father dying when he was a child. <a href="Keisuke%20Kuwata">Keisuke Kuwata</a>, who grew up in a dual-income family, was influenced by the Beatles through his older sister, then an avid fan. <a href="Y%C5%8Dsui%20Inoue">Yōsui Inoue</a> was also a fan of The Beatles, but he said that his music style was not particularly related to them. After Happy End disbanded in 1973, <a href="Haruomi%20Hosono">Haruomi Hosono</a>, a former member, began a solo career and later formed <a href="Yellow%20Magic%20Orchestra">Yellow Magic Orchestra</a>.
1970s: Development of "new music".
"Fōku" and new music.
In the early 1960s, some Japanese music became influenced by the <a href="American%20folk%20music%20revival">American folk music revival</a>; this was called , although the genre of music was mostly covers of original songs. In the late 1960s, <a href="the%20Folk%20Crusaders">the Folk Crusaders</a> became famous and the underground music around that time became called "fōku". As with "enka", Japanese "fōku" singers Wataru Takada performed social satires.
In the early 1970s, the emphasis shifted from "fōku"s simple songs with a single guitar accompaniment to more complex musical arrangements known as . Instead of social messages, the songs focused on more personal messages, such as love. In 1972, singer-songwriter <a href="Takuro%20Yoshida">Takuro Yoshida</a> produced a hit song "Kekkon Shiyouyo" ("Let's marry") without decent television promotion, though fans of "fōku" music became very angry because his music seemed to be a mersh music. The highest-selling single of the year was the "enka" song by <a href="Shiro%20Miya">Shiro Miya</a> and the Pinkara Trio, "<a href="Onna%20no%20Michi">Onna no Michi</a>". The song eventually sold over 3.25 million copies. On December 1, 1973, <a href="Y%C5%8Dsui%20Inoue">Yōsui Inoue</a> released the album "<a href="K%C5%8Dri%20no%20Sekai">Kōri no Sekai</a>", which topped the Oricon charts and remained in Top 10 for 113 weeks. It spent 13 consecutive weeks in the number-one spot, and eventually established a still-standing record of a total 35 weeks at the number-one position on the Oricon charts. <a href="Yumi%20Matsutoya">Yumi Matsutoya</a>, formerly known by her maiden name Yumi Arai, also became a notable singer-songwriter during this period In October 1975, she released a single "Ano Hi ni Kaeritai" ("I want to return to that day"), making it her first number-one single on the Oricon charts. <a href="Miyuki%20Nakajima">Miyuki Nakajima</a>, <a href="Amii%20Ozaki">Amii Ozaki</a>, and <a href="Junko%20Yagami">Junko Yagami</a> were also popular singer-songwriters during this period. At first, only Yumi Matsutoya was commonly called a new music artist, but the concept of Japanese "fōku" music changed around that time. In 1979, <a href="Chage%20and%20Aska">Chage and Aska</a> made their debut, and folk band <a href="Off%20Course">Off Course</a> (with singer <a href="Kazumasa%20Oda">Kazumasa Oda</a>) released a hit song "Sayonara" ("Good-bye").
Emergence of Japanese rock and electronic music.
<a href="Rock%20music">Rock music</a> remained a relatively <a href="underground%20music">underground music</a> genre in the early 1970s in Japan, though <a href="Happy%20End%20%28band%29">Happy End</a> managed to gain mainstream success fusing rock with traditional <a href="Music%20of%20Japan">Japanese music</a>. Several Japanese musicians began experimenting with <a href="electronic%20music">electronic music</a>, including <a href="electronic%20rock">electronic rock</a>. The most notable was the internationally renowned <a href="Isao%20Tomita">Isao Tomita</a>, whose 1972 album "Electric Samurai: Switched on Rock" featured electronic <a href="synthesizer">synthesizer</a> renditions of contemporary rock and <a href="Pop%20music">pop songs</a>. Other early examples of electronic rock records include <a href="Inoue%20Yousui">Inoue Yousui</a>'s <a href="folk%20rock">folk rock</a> and <a href="pop%20rock">pop rock</a> album "Ice World" (1973) and <a href="Osamu%20Kitajima">Osamu Kitajima</a>'s <a href="Progressive%20rock">progressive</a> <a href="psychedelic%20rock">psychedelic rock</a> album "<a href="Benzaiten">Benzaiten</a>" (1974), both of which involved contributions from Haruomi Hosono, who later started the electronic music group "Yellow Magic Band" (later known as Yellow Magic Orchestra) in 1977.
In 1978, <a href="Eikichi%20Yazawa">Eikichi Yazawa</a>'s rock single "Jikan yo Tomare" ("Time, Stop") became a smash hit that sold over 639,000 copies. He is regarded as one of the pioneers of Japanese rock. He sought worldwide success, and in 1980 he signed a contract with the Warner Pioneer record company and moved to the West Coast of the United States. He recorded the albums "Yazawa", "It's Just Rock n' Roll", and "Flash in Japan", all of which were released worldwide, but were not very commercially successful. <a href="Keisuke%20Kuwata">Keisuke Kuwata</a> formed the rock band <a href="Southern%20All%20Stars">Southern All Stars</a> (SAS), which made their debut in 1978. Southern All Stars remains very popular in Japan today.
In the same year, <a href="Yellow%20Magic%20Orchestra">Yellow Magic Orchestra</a> (YMO) also made their official debut with their <a href="Yellow%20Magic%20Orchestra%20%28album%29">self-titled album</a>. The band, whose members were <a href="Haruomi%20Hosono">Haruomi Hosono</a>, <a href="Yukihiro%20Takahashi">Yukihiro Takahashi</a> and <a href="Ryuichi%20Sakamoto">Ryuichi Sakamoto</a>, developed <a href="electropop">electropop</a>, or <a href="techno">techno</a>pop as it is known in Japan, in addition to pioneering <a href="synthpop">synthpop</a> and <a href="electro%20music">electro music</a>. Their 1979 album "<a href="Solid%20State%20Survivor">Solid State Survivor</a>" reached number one on the <a href="Oricon">Oricon</a> charts in July 1980, and went on to sell two million records worldwide. At around the same time, the YMO albums "Solid State Survivor" and "<a href="X%E2%88%9EMultiplies">X∞Multiplies</a>" held both the top two spots on the <a href="Oricon">Oricon</a> charts for seven consecutive weeks, making YMO the only band in Japanese chart history to achieve this feat. Young fans of their music during this period became known as the . YMO had a significant impact on Japanese pop music, which started becoming increasingly dominated by <a href="electronic%20music">electronic music</a> due to their influence, and they had an equally large impact on electronic music across the world. Southern All Stars and Yellow Magic Orchestra symbolized the end of New Music and paved the way for the emergence of the J-pop genre in the 1980s. Both bands, SAS and YMO, would later be ranked at the top of <a href="HMV%20Group">HMV Japan</a>'s list of top 100 Japanese musicians of all time.
1980s: Fusion with "kayōkyoku".
City pop.
In the early 1980s, with the spread of <a href="car%20stereo">car stereo</a>s, the term came to describe a type of popular music that had a big city theme. <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> in particular inspired many songs of this form. During this time, music fans and artists in Japan were influenced by <a href="album-oriented%20rock">album-oriented rock</a> (especially <a href="Adult%20contemporary%20music">adult contemporary</a>) and <a href="crossover%20%28music%29">crossover</a> (especially <a href="jazz%20fusion">jazz fusion</a>). City pop was affected by new music, though its origins have been traced back to the mid-1970s, with the work of the Japanese rock band <a href="Happy%20End%20%28band%29">Happy End</a> and its former member <a href="Haruomi%20Hosono">Haruomi Hosono</a>, as well as <a href="Tatsuro%20Yamashita">Tatsuro Yamashita</a>.
The popularity of city pop declined when the <a href="Japanese%20asset%20price%20bubble">Japanese asset price bubble</a> burst in 1990. Its musical characteristics (except its "cultural background") were inherited by 1990s <a href="Shibuya-kei">Shibuya-kei</a> musicians such as <a href="Pizzicato%20Five">Pizzicato Five</a> and <a href="Flipper%27s%20Guitar">Flipper's Guitar</a>.
Growth of the Japanese rock industry.
Throughout the 1980s, rock bands such as <a href="Southern%20All%20Stars">Southern All Stars</a>, <a href="RC%20Succession">RC Succession</a>, <a href="Anzen%20Chitai">Anzen Chitai</a>, <a href="The%20Checkers%20%28Japanese%20band%29">The Checkers</a>, <a href="The%20Alfee">The Alfee</a>, and <a href="The%20Blue%20Hearts">The Blue Hearts</a> became popular. Anzen Chitai came from <a href="Yosui%20Inoue">Yosui Inoue</a>'s backup band. On December 1, 1983, rock singer <a href="Yutaka%20Ozaki">Yutaka Ozaki</a> debuted at the age of 18. In 1986, The Alfee became the first artists to play a concert in front of an audience of 100,000 people in Japan. Some Japanese musicians, such as <a href="Bo%C3%B8wy">Boøwy</a>, <a href="TM%20Network">TM Network</a>, and <a href="Buck-Tick">Buck-Tick</a>, were influenced by <a href="New%20Romanticism">New Romanticism</a>.
Boøwy became an especially influential rock band, whose members included singer <a href="Kyosuke%20Himuro">Kyosuke Himuro</a> and guitarist <a href="Tomoyasu%20Hotei">Tomoyasu Hotei</a>. Their three albums reached number one in 1988, making them the first male artists to have three number-ones within a single year. Subsequent Japanese rock bands were modeled on this band. Guitarist <a href="Tak%20Matsumoto">Tak Matsumoto</a>, who supported TM Network's concerts, formed rock duo <a href="B%27z">B'z</a> with singer <a href="Koshi%20Inaba">Koshi Inaba</a> in 1988.
In the late 1980s, <a href="all-female%20band">girl band</a> <a href="Princess%20Princess%20%28band%29">Princess Princess</a> became a successful pop-rock band. Their singles "Diamonds" and "Sekai de Ichiban Atsui Natsu" ("World's Hottest Summer") were ranked at the number-one and number-two spots, respectively, on the 1989 Oricon Yearly Single Charts.
In the late 1980s, a new trend also emerged in Japanese rock music: the "<a href="visual%20kei">visual kei</a>", a movement notable by male bands who wore makeup, extravagant hair styles, and androgynous costumes. The most successful representatives of the movement are <a href="X%20Japan">X Japan</a> (formerly known as "X") and <a href="Buck-Tick">Buck-Tick</a>. X Japan released their first album "<a href="Vanishing%20Vision">Vanishing Vision</a>" on the indie label <a href="Extasy%20Records">Extasy Records</a> in 1988; their album "<a href="Blue%20Blood%20%28X%20Japan%20album%29">Blue Blood</a>" was released on <a href="Sony%20Music%20Entertainment%20Japan">CBS Sony</a> in 1989. "Blue Blood" sold 712,000 copies, and their 1991 album "<a href="Jealousy%20%28X%20Japan%20album%29">Jealousy</a>" sold over 1.11 million copies. Surprisingly, X Japan were a <a href="heavy%20metal%20music">heavy metal</a> band, but guitarist <a href="Hide%20%28musician%29">hide</a> later came under the influence of <a href="alternative%20rock">alternative rock</a>, releasing his first solo album "<a href="Hide%20Your%20Face">Hide Your Face</a>" in 1994 and launching his successful solo career.
Golden age, decline and transfiguration of Idols.
In the 1970s, the popularity of female <a href="Japanese%20idol">idol</a> singers such as <a href="Mari%20Amachi">Mari Amachi</a>, <a href="Saori%20Minami">Saori Minami</a>, <a href="Momoe%20Yamaguchi">Momoe Yamaguchi</a>, and <a href="Candies%20%28group%29">Candies</a> increased. Momoe Yamaguchi was one of the first "<a href="kay%C5%8Dkyoku">kayōkyoku</a>" singers to use the special pronunciation characteristic of J-pop. In 1972, <a href="Hiromi%20Go">Hiromi Go</a> made his debut with the song "Otokonoko Onnanoko" ("Boy and Girl"). Hiromi Go originally came from <a href="Johnny%20%26amp%3B%20Associates">Johnny & Associates</a>.
In 1976, female duo <a href="Pink%20Lady%20%28duo%29">Pink Lady</a> made their debut with the single "<a href="Pepper%20Keibu">Pepper Keibu</a>". They released a record nine consecutive number-one singles.
In the 1980s, Japanese idols inherited New Music, though the term fell out of usage. <a href="Seiko%20Matsuda">Seiko Matsuda</a> especially adopted song producers of previous generations. In 1980, her third single "Kaze wa Aki Iro" ("Wind is autumn color") reached the number-one spot on the Oricon charts. <a href="Haruomi%20Hosono">Haruomi Hosono</a> also joined the production of her music. She eventually became the first artist to make 24 consecutive number-one singles, breaking Pink Lady's record.
Other female idol singers achieved significant popularity in the 1980s, such as <a href="Akina%20Nakamori">Akina Nakamori</a>, <a href="Yukiko%20Okada">Yukiko Okada</a>, <a href="Ky%C5%8Dko%20Koizumi">Kyōko Koizumi</a>, <a href="Yoko%20Minamino">Yoko Minamino</a>, <a href="Momoko%20Kikuchi">Momoko Kikuchi</a>, <a href="Y%C5%8Dko%20Oginome">Yōko Oginome</a>, <a href="Miho%20Nakayama">Miho Nakayama</a>, <a href="Minako%20Honda">Minako Honda</a>, and <a href="Chisato%20Moritaka">Chisato Moritaka</a>. Okada received the Best New Artist award from the <a href="Japan%20Record%20Award">Japan Record Award</a>s in 1984. Nakamori won the Grand Prix award for two consecutive years (1985 and 1986), also at the Japan Record Awards.
Japanese idol band <a href="Onyanko%20Club">Onyanko Club</a> made their debut in 1985, and produced popular singer <a href="Shizuka%20Kud%C5%8D">Shizuka Kudō</a>. They changed the image of Japanese idols.
Around 1985, however, people began to be disenchanted with the system for creating idols. In 1986, idol singer <a href="Yukiko%20Okada">Yukiko Okada</a>'s song "Kuchibiru Network" ("Lips' Network"), written by Seiko Matsuda and composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto, became a hit song, but she committed suicide immediately after that.
<a href="Hikaru%20Genji%20%28band%29">Hikaru Genji</a>, one of the <a href="Johnny%20%26amp%3B%20Associates">Johnny & Associates</a> bands, made their debut in 1987. They became a highly influential rollerskating boy band, with some of their members gaining their own fame as they got older. Their song "Paradise Ginga", written by <a href="Aska%20%28singer%29">Aska</a>, won the Grand Prix award at the <a href="30th%20Japan%20Record%20Awards">30th Japan Record Awards</a> in 1988. Some of the group's backing dancers later formed <a href="SMAP">SMAP</a>.
The late 1980s also saw the rise of the female duo <a href="Wink%20%28Japanese%20band%29">Wink</a>. They didn't laugh, unlike Japanese idols of former eras. Wink debuted in 1988, surpassing the popularity of the then-most popular female duo, <a href="BaBe">BaBe</a>. Wink's song "<a href="Samishii%20Nettaigyo">Samishii Nettaigyo</a>" won the grand prix award at the <a href="31st%20Japan%20Record%20Awards">31st Japan Record Awards</a> in 1989.
Popular singer <a href="Hibari%20Misora">Hibari Misora</a> died in 1989, and many "kayōkyoku" programs, such as "The Best Ten", were closed.
<a href="CoCo%20%28group%29">CoCo</a> made their hit debut with the 1989 single "Equal Romance" for the hit <a href="anime">anime</a> series "<a href="Ranma%20%C2%BD">Ranma ½</a>". <a href="Tetsuya%20Komuro">Tetsuya Komuro</a>, a member of TM Network, broke Seiko Matsuda's streak of 25 consecutive number-ones by making his single "Gravity of Love" to debut at number-one in November 1989.
1990s: Coining of the term "J-pop".
1990–1997: Growing market.
In the 1990s, the term J-pop came to refer to all Japanese popular songs except "<a href="enka">enka</a>".
During this period, the Japanese music industry sought <a href="marketing%20effectiveness">marketing effectiveness</a>. Notable examples of commercial music from the era were the <a href="tie-in">tie-in</a> music from the agency <a href="Being%20%28company%29">Being</a> and the follow-on, <a href="Tetsuya%20Komuro">Tetsuya Komuro</a>'s <a href="disco">disco</a> music.
The period between around 1990 and 1993 was dominated by artists from <a href="being%20Inc.">the Being agency</a>, including <a href="B%27z">B'z</a>, <a href="Tube%20%28band%29">Tube</a>, <a href="B.B.Queens">B.B.Queens</a>, <a href="T-Bolan">T-Bolan</a>, <a href="Zard">Zard</a>, <a href="Wands%20%28band%29">Wands</a>, <a href="Maki%20Ohguro">Maki Ohguro</a>, <a href="Deen%20%28band%29">Deen</a>, and <a href="Field%20of%20View">Field of View</a>. They were called the . Many of those artists topped the charts and established new records, notably B'z, which eventually established a new record for consecutive number-one singles, surpassing Seiko Matsuda's record. B'z is the Japanese biggest selling artist of all time, according to Oricon charts and RIAJ certifications. On the other hand, Wands, regarded as a pioneer of the "J-pop Boom" of the 1990s, had trouble because member Show Wesugi wanted to play <a href="alternative%20rock">alternative rock</a>/<a href="grunge">grunge</a>.
Many artists surpassed the two-million-copy mark in the 1990s. <a href="Kazumasa%20Oda">Kazumasa Oda</a>'s 1991 single "Oh! Yeah!/Love Story wa Totsuzen ni", <a href="Chage%20and%20Aska">Chage and Aska</a>'s 1991 single "<a href="Say%20Yes%20%28Chage%20and%20Aska%20song%29">Say Yes</a>" and 1993 single "Yah Yah Yah", <a href="Kome%20Kome%20Club">Kome Kome Club</a>'s 1992 single "<a href="Kimi%20ga%20Iru%20Dake%20de">Kimi ga Iru Dake de</a>", <a href="Mr.%20Children">Mr. Children</a>'s 1994 single "<a href="Tomorrow%20Never%20Knows%20%28Mr.%20Children%20song%29">Tomorrow Never Knows</a>" and 1996 single "<a href="Namonaki%20Uta">Namonaki Uta</a>", and <a href="Globe%20%28band%29">Globe</a>'s 1996 single "Departures" are examples of songs that sold more than 2 million copies. <a href="Dreams%20Come%20True%20%28band%29">Dreams Come True</a>'s 1992 album "<a href="The%20Swinging%20Star">The Swinging Star</a>" became the first album to sell over 3 million copies in Japan. Mr. Children's 1994 album "<a href="Atomic%20Heart%20%28album%29">Atomic Heart</a>" established a new record, selling 3.43 million copies on Oricon charts.
The duo Chage and Aska, who started recording in late 1979, became very popular during this period. They released a string of consecutive hits throughout the early 1990s; in 1996, they took part in "<a href="MTV%20Unplugged">MTV Unplugged</a>", making them the first Asian group to do so.
After <a href="TM%20Network">TM Network</a> disbanded in 1994, <a href="Tetsuya%20Komuro">Tetsuya Komuro</a> became a serious song producer. The period between 1994 and 1997 was dominated by dance and techno acts from the , such as <a href="TRF%20%28band%29">TRF</a>, <a href="Ryoko%20Shinohara">Ryoko Shinohara</a>, <a href="Yuki%20Uchida">Yuki Uchida</a>, <a href="Namie%20Amuro">Namie Amuro</a>, <a href="Hitomi%20%28singer%29">Hitomi</a>, <a href="Globe%20%28band%29">Globe</a>, <a href="Tomomi%20Kahala">Tomomi Kahala</a>, and <a href="Ami%20Suzuki">Ami Suzuki</a>. In that time, Komuro was responsible for 20 hit songs, each selling more than a million copies. While Globe's 1996 album "<a href="Globe%20%28album%29">Globe</a>" sold 4.13 million copies, establishing a record at the time, Namie Amuro's 1997 song "<a href="Can%20You%20Celebrate%3F">Can You Celebrate?</a>" sold 2.29 million copies, is the best selling single of all time by the female solo artist in the history of Jpop. His total sales as a song producer reached 170 million copies. By 1998, Komuro's songs had become less popular. By the middle part of the first decade of the 21st century, Komuro's debt lead him to attempt the sale of his song catalog—which he didn't actually own—to an investor. When the investor found out and sued, Komuro tried to sell the catalog to "another" investor in order to pay the judgement he owed the first investor.
<a href="Namie%20Amuro">Namie Amuro</a>, who was arguably the most popular solo singer in the period, came from the "<a href="Okinawa%20Actors%20School">Okinawa Actors School</a>", which also incubated the bands <a href="MAX%20%28band%29">MAX</a> and <a href="Speed%20%28Japanese%20band%29">Speed</a>. At first, while still a part of the Komuro Family, Amuro remained in the dance music genre, but she slowly changed her music style to <a href="contemporary%20R%26amp%3BB">contemporary R&B</a> and ended her partnership with Tetsuya Komuro.
Komuro's band Globe became a <a href="Trance%20music">trance</a> band after their 2001 album "Outernet".
1997–1999: Commercial peak.
The sales in the Japanese music market continued to increase. In October 1997, <a href="Glay">Glay</a> released their album "<a href="Review%20%28Glay%20album%29">Review -The Best of Glay</a>", which sold 4.87 million copies, breaking Globe's earlier record. However, it was surpassed in the next year by <a href="B%27z">B'z</a>'s album "<a href="B%27z%20The%20Best%20%26quot%3BPleasure%26quot%3B">B'z The Best "Pleasure"</a>", which sold 5.12 million copies. The Japanese market for physical music sales peaked in 1998, recording sales of . In March 1999, <a href="Hikaru%20Utada">Hikaru Utada</a> released her first Japanese album, "<a href="First%20Love%20%28Hikaru%20Utada%20album%29">First Love</a>", which sold 7.65 million copies, making it the best-selling album in <a href="Oricon">Oricon</a> history.
The late 1990s saw the popularity of rock bands, such as <a href="Glay">Glay</a>, <a href="Luna%20Sea">Luna Sea</a>, and <a href="L%27Arc-en-Ciel">L'Arc-en-Ciel</a>, most of them related to the "<a href="visual%20kei">visual kei</a>" movement, though they later changed their style. At the time, rock musicians in Japan were absorbing "kayōkyoku" music after the genre vanished. Glay became especially successful, with massive exposure in the media, comparable to that of the most popular pop singers produced by Tetsuya Komuro. In July 1999, Glay played a concert to a record audience of 200,000 people at the <a href="Makuhari%20Messe">Makuhari Messe</a>, certified by <a href="Guinness%20World%20Records">Guinness World Records</a> as the biggest solo concert in Japan. In July 1999, L'Arc-en-Ciel released two albums, "<a href="Ark%20%28L%27Arc-en-Ciel%20album%29">Arc</a>" and "<a href="Ray%20%28L%27Arc-en-Ciel%20album%29">Ray</a>", at the same time; they sold over 3.02 million combined copies in the first week of release.
<a href="X%20Japan">X Japan</a> announced their disbandment in September 1997 and their guitarist <a href="Hide%20%28musician%29">hide</a> died in May 1998. His funeral had a record attendance of 50,000 people, breaking the record of <a href="Hibari%20Misora">Hibari Misora</a>, whose funeral was attended by 42,000 people. After his death, his single "<a href="Pink%20Spider">Pink Spider</a>" and album "<a href="Ja%2C%20Zoo">Ja, Zoo</a>" were certified million-sellers by the <a href="Recording%20Industry%20Association%20of%20Japan">Recording Industry Association of Japan</a>.
<a href="Johnny%20%26amp%3B%20Associates">Johnny & Associates</a> produced many all-male groups: <a href="SMAP">SMAP</a>, <a href="Tokio%20%28band%29">Tokio</a>, <a href="V6%20%28band%29">V6</a>, <a href="KinKi%20Kids">KinKi Kids</a> and <a href="Arashi">Arashi</a>. SMAP hit the J-pop scene in a major way in the 1990s through a combination of TV "<a href="Tarento">Tarento</a>" shows and singles, with one of its singers, <a href="Takuya%20Kimura">Takuya Kimura</a>, becoming a popular actor commonly known as "Kimutaku" in later years.
By the late 1990s, the girl group <a href="Speed%20%28Japanese%20band%29">Speed</a> was very popular; they announced their disbandment in 1999. The group returned to the music scene in 2008. Another all-female band, <a href="Morning%20Musume">Morning Musume</a>, produced by <a href="Tsunku">Tsunku</a>, former leader of band <a href="Sharam%20Q">Sharam Q</a> became very popular, with a string of releases that were sales hits before even being released. The group's popularity gave origin to the <a href="Hello%21%20Project">Hello! Project</a>. Following the pattern set a decade before by the 1980s all-female <a href="Onyanko%20Club">Onyanko Club</a>, Morning Musume spawned several splinter bands.
In the late 1990s and early 21st century, female singers such as <a href="Hikaru%20Utada">Hikaru Utada</a>, <a href="Ayumi%20Hamasaki">Ayumi Hamasaki</a>, <a href="Misia%20%28singer%29">Misia</a>, <a href="Mai%20Kuraki">Mai Kuraki</a>, and <a href="Ringo%20Shiina">Ringo Shiina</a> became chart-toppers who write their own songs or their own lyrics. Hikaru Utada is the daughter of <a href="Keiko%20Fuji">Keiko Fuji</a>, a popular singer of the 1970s. Ayumi Hamasaki was made Utada's contemporary rival, though both women claimed the "competition" was merely a creation of their record companies and the media.
<a href="Zeebra">Zeebra</a> introduced <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop music</a> to Japanese mainstream music. In 1999, was featured by <a href="Dragon%20Ash">Dragon Ash</a> in their song titled "<a href="Grateful%20Days">Grateful Days</a>", which topped the Oricon charts.
2000s: Diversification.
Avex group.
<a href="Ayumi%20Hamasaki">Ayumi Hamasaki</a> won Grand Prix awards for three consecutive years—the first time in <a href="Japan%20Record%20Award">Japan Record Award</a> history—between 2001 and 2003. Although Hamasaki became very famous, <a href="Tom%20Yoda">Tom Yoda</a>, then-chairman of her record company <a href="Avex%20Group">Avex Group</a>, argued that her tactics were risky, because Avex disregarded the <a href="modern%20portfolio%20theory">modern portfolio theory</a>. This concern disappeared when the company's other singers (such as <a href="Ai%20Otsuka">Ai Otsuka</a>, <a href="Kumi%20Koda">Kumi Koda</a>, and <a href="Exile%20%28Japanese%20band%29">Exile</a>) also reached a certain level of popularity in the mid-2000s under Yoda's management policy. <a href="BoA">BoA</a>, a Korean singer also a part of Avex group, also achieved high levels of success although being Korean in Japan. She opened the Hallyu door to other Korean artists so that they may achieve varying levels of success in Japan as well.
"Chaku-uta".
In December 2002, the digital-download market for was created by mobile-phone company <a href="au%20%28mobile%20phone%20company%29">au</a>. The market for digital downloads grew rapidly, and <a href="Hikaru%20Utada">Hikaru Utada</a>'s 2007 song "<a href="Flavor%20of%20Life">Flavor of Life</a>" sold over 7 million downloaded copies. In October 2007, <a href="EMI%20Music%20Japan">EMI Music Japan</a> announced that Utada was the world's first artist to have 10 million digital sales in one year. According to the <a href="International%20Federation%20of%20the%20Phonographic%20Industry">International Federation of the Phonographic Industry</a>'s 2009 digital music report, <a href="Thelma%20Aoyama">Thelma Aoyama</a>'s digital single "<a href="Soba%20ni%20Iru%20ne">Soba ni Iru ne</a>" and <a href="Greeeen">Greeeen</a>'s digital single "<a href="Kiseki%20%28Greeeen%20song%29">Kiseki</a>" sold 8.2 million copies and 6.2 million copies, respectively, in the 2008 download rankings.
Japanese hip hop and urban pop.
In the first decade of the 21st century, <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop music</a> and <a href="contemporary%20R%26amp%3BB">contemporary R&B</a> influences in Japanese music started to gain attention in popular mainstream music. In November 2001, R&B duo <a href="Chemistry%20%28band%29">Chemistry</a>'s debut album "<a href="The%20Way%20We%20Are%20%28Chemistry%20album%29">The Way We Are</a>" sold over 1.14 million copies in the first week, and debuted at the number-one position on the Oricon weekly album charts. Hip hop bands such as <a href="Rip%20Slyme">Rip Slyme</a> and <a href="Ketsumeishi">Ketsumeishi</a> were also at the top of the <a href="Oricon">Oricon</a> charts.
Rock band <a href="Orange%20Range">Orange Range</a> featured several elements of hip hop in their music. Orange Range's album "<a href="musiQ">musiQ</a>" sold over 2.6 million copies, making it the number one album of 2005 on the Oricon charts.
Pop/R&B singer <a href="Ken%20Hirai">Ken Hirai</a> topped the Oricon yearly album chart in 2006 with the release of his greatest hits album "10th Anniversary Complete Single Collection '95-'05 Utabaka", selling over 2 million copies.
The pop/hip-hop duo, <a href="Halcali">Halcali</a>, have the honor of being the first Japanese female hip-hop artists to break the <a href="Oricon">Oricon</a> top 10 charts. They have also performed overseas two times in 2008, once at the <a href="Anime%20Central">Anime Central</a> festival in Chicago, and once more at <a href="Central%20Park">Central Park</a>, NYC on Japan Day.
<a href="Exile%20%28Japanese%20band%29">Exile</a>, the dance-vocal group under Avex's sublabel <a href="Rhythm%20Zone">Rhythm Zone</a>, had several million-seller albums. Their album "Exile Love" topped the Oricon yearly album chart in 2008.
Veteran rapper <a href="Dohzi-T">Dohzi-T</a> collaborated with popular singers such as <a href="Shota%20Shimizu">Shota Shimizu</a>, <a href="Hiromi%20Go">Hiromi Go</a>, <a href="Miliyah%20Kato">Miliyah Kato</a>, and <a href="Thelma%20Aoyama">Thelma Aoyama</a> in his successful 2008 album "<a href="12%20Love%20Stories">12 Love Stories</a>".
Although there were only 132 new artists in Japan in 2001, according to the <a href="Recording%20Industry%20Association%20of%20Japan">Recording Industry Association of Japan</a>, the number increased to 512 in 2008. In 2008, 14 new artists, such as Thelma Aoyama, attended the <a href="NHK">NHK</a> <a href="K%C5%8Dhaku%20Uta%20Gassen">Kōhaku Uta Gassen</a> for the first time.
Popularity of live performances and veteran musicians.
Rock musicians such as <a href="Mr.%20Children">Mr. Children</a>, <a href="B%27z">B'z</a>, <a href="Southern%20All%20Stars">Southern All Stars</a>, and <a href="Glay">Glay</a> still topped the charts in the first decade of the 21st century. Mr. Children's song "<a href="Sign%20%28Mr.%20Children%20song%29">Sign</a>" won the Grand Prix award at the <a href="46th%20Japan%20Record%20Awards">46th Japan Record Awards</a> in 2004. When the group released their album "<a href="Home%20%28Mr.%20Children%20album%29">Home</a>" in 2007, they passed 50 million albums and singles sold, making them the second-highest selling artist of all time in Japan since the origin of Oricon—just behind B'z, who held the number-one position with more than 75 million records sold until then. "Home" topped the 2007 Oricon yearly album charts.
The sales of physical CDs declined, but audiences to see live performances increased. <a href="Eikichi%20Yazawa">Eikichi Yazawa</a> took part in <a href="rock%20festival">rock festival</a>s, and, in 2007, he became the first artist to have performed 100 concerts at the <a href="Nippon%20Budokan">Nippon Budokan</a>.
Other artists, such as <a href="Namie%20Amuro">Namie Amuro</a>, also continued their long-running careers with successful releases in this period. Her live tour, <a href="Namie%20Amuro%20Best%20Fiction%20tour%202008-2009">Namie Amuro Best Fiction tour 2008-2009</a>, not only became the biggest live tour by a Japanese solo female artist—attended by 450,000 fans in Japan—but was also attended by 50,000 fans in <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> and <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>. While <a href="Kazumasa%20Oda">Kazumasa Oda</a>'s 2005 album "Sōkana" topped the Oricon weekly album charts, his 2007 single "Kokoro" reached the weekly single charts, breaking <a href="Yujiro%20Ishihara">Yujiro Ishihara</a>'s record and making him the then-oldest singer to top the single charts. <a href="Mariya%20Takeuchi">Mariya Takeuchi</a>'s greatest hits album "Expressions" topped the Oricon album chart in 2008, making her the oldest female singer with the longest active career to reach the number-one position.
Johnny & Associates.
<a href="Johnny%20%26amp%3B%20Associates">Johnny & Associates</a>'s all-male groups remained well-known. In 2001, <a href="SMAP">SMAP</a> released their greatest-hits album "SMAP Vest", which sold over a million copies in the first week. In November 2001, Johnny & Associates established the label <a href="J%20Storm">J Storm</a> for their band <a href="Arashi">Arashi</a>. SMAP's 2003 single "Sekai ni hitotsu dake no hana" sold more than two million copies, being the number-one single in the Oricon yearly single charts for that year. In 2007, Guinness World Records honored <a href="KinKi%20Kids">KinKi Kids</a> for holding a world record for the number of singles debuting at the number-one position since their debut: 25. SMAP was said to fight a lonely battle at the <a href="K%C5%8Dhaku%20Uta%20Gassen">Kōhaku Uta Gassen</a>, as seen from the viewpoint of its audience share. In 2008, male musicians established a record of four consecutive wins at the Kōhaku Uta Gassen. Arashi's greatest hits album "<a href="All%20the%20Best%21%201999%E2%80%932009">All the Best! 1999–2009</a>" topped the 2009 Oricon yearly album charts.
Johnny & Associates also produced new groups such as <a href="Hey%21%20Say%21%20JUMP">Hey! Say! JUMP</a>, <a href="Tackey%20%26amp%3B%20Tsubasa">Tackey & Tsubasa</a>, <a href="News%20%28band%29">NEWS</a>, <a href="Kanjani%20Eight">Kanjani Eight</a>, and <a href="KAT-TUN">KAT-TUN</a>. In 2006, KAT-TUN's debut single "<a href="Real%20Face">Real Face</a>", written by <a href="Shikao%20Suga">Shikao Suga</a> and composed by <a href="Tak%20Matsumoto">Tak Matsumoto</a>, sold over one million copies and topped the Oricon Yearly Charts. In 2007, temporary <a href="Johnny%27s%20Jr.">Johnny's Jr.</a> group <a href="Hey%21%20Say%21%20JUMP">Hey! Say! 7</a> broke a record as the youngest male group to ever top Oricon charts, with an average age of 14.8 years. Later that year, <a href="Hey%21%20Say%21%20JUMP">Hey! Say! JUMP</a> broke a record as the largest group to debut in <a href="Johnny%27s%20Entertainment">Johnny's</a> history, with ten members. They also became the youngest group ever to perform in Tokyo Dome with the average age of 15.7 years old. On the 2008 yearly singles charts, only one single ranked in the top 30 was sung by a female (Namie Amuro's single "<a href="60s%2070s%2080s">60s 70s 80s</a>") except gender-mixed groups, partly because the boy bands enjoyed an advantage in physical single sales. In 2009, Johnny's Jr. artist <a href="Yuma%20Nakayama%20w/B.I.Shadow">Yuma Nakayama w/B.I.Shadow</a> became the youngest artist to have their first single to debut at the number-one spot, as the band had an average age of 14.6 years, breaking the former record set by female group <a href="Minimoni">Minimoni</a>, 14.8 years.
Cover versions and classical pop.
In February 2001, <a href="Ulfuls">Ulfuls</a> released their <a href="cover%20version">cover version</a> of <a href="Kyu%20Sakamoto">Kyu Sakamoto</a>'s 1963 song "<a href="Ashita%20Ga%20Arusa">Ashita Ga Arusa</a>". Their cover version debuted at the number-five position, behind Utada, Kinki Kids, Hamasaki and Hirai. In March, <a href="Yoshimoto%20Kogyo">Yoshimoto Kogyo</a>'s special band "Re: Japan" also released their cover version of "Ashita Ga Arusa". When Ulfuls's cover version of this song remained at number eight, Re: Japan's version topped the Oricon weekly single charts.
In 2003, Man Arai released the single "Sen no Kaze ni Natte" ("As A Thousand Winds") based on the Western poem "<a href="Do%20not%20stand%20at%20my%20grave%20and%20weep">Do not stand at my grave and weep</a>". In Japan, the poem was known for <a href="Rokusuke%20Ei">Rokusuke Ei</a>'s reading at the funeral of Kyu Sakamoto in 1985. Japanese tenor singer <a href="Masafumi%20Akikawa">Masafumi Akikawa</a> covered the song in 2006. Akikawa's cover version of the song became the first <a href="classical%20music">classical music</a> single to top the Oricon charts, and sold over one million copies. On the 2007 Oricon Yearly Charts, the single became the best-selling physical single, scoring a victory over Utada's "Flavor of Life". Oricon claimed that the song was not J-pop. On the other hand, sheet music from the <a href="Zen-On%20Music%20Company%20Ltd">Zen-On Music Company Ltd</a> classified the song as J-pop.
<a href="Hideaki%20Tokunaga">Hideaki Tokunaga</a> covered many female songs on his cover album series, "Vocalist". He released "Vocalist", "Vocalist 2", "Vocalist 3", "Vocalist 4" and "Vocalist Vintage (Vocalist 5)" in 2005, 2006, 2007, 2010, and 2012 respectively. In August 2007, "Vocalist 3" became Oricon weekly number-one cover album with 2 weeks (tied the record in Japan), and in May 2010, "Vocalist 4" became the Japan first Oricon monthly number-one cover album.
In 2010, other singers also released cover albums of Japanese songs such as <a href="Juju%20%28singer%29">Juju</a>'s "<a href="Request%20%28Juju%20album%29">Request</a>" and Kumi Koda's '. <a href="Superfly%20%28band%29">Superfly</a> released a single that came with a cover album of Western rock songs, titled ', ultimately becoming the band's third consecutive album to debut at number one on the Oricon weekly album charts.
Influence from neofolk and neo Shibuya-kei.
Folk duos, such as <a href="19%20%28band%29">19</a>, <a href="Yuzu%20%28band%29">Yuzu</a> and <a href="Kobukuro">Kobukuro</a>, became popular during the period. Their music was called "neofolk". In October 2007, Kobukuro's double-album "All Singles Best" became the first male album to ship three million copies in the 21st century in Japan. In January 2008, their album "<a href="5296">5296</a>" beat out Ayumi Hamasaki's album "<a href="Guilty%20%28Ayumi%20Hamasaki%20album%29">Guilty</a>" on the Oricon charts, though she previously had eight consecutive number-one studio albums.
Electronic music bands such as <a href="Plus-Tech%20Squeeze%20Box">Plus-Tech Squeeze Box</a> and <a href="Capsule%20%28band%29">Capsule</a> were called "<a href="neo%20Shibuya-kei">neo Shibuya-kei</a>". <a href="Yasutaka%20Nakata">Yasutaka Nakata</a>, a member of Capsule, became the song producer for girl group <a href="Perfume%20%28Japanese%20band%29">Perfume</a>. In April 2008, for the first time as a technopop band in 25 years since Yellow Magic Orchestra's 1983 album "<a href="Naughty%20Boys">Naughty Boys</a>", Perfume achieved a number-one album "<a href="Game%20%28Perfume%20album%29">Game</a>" on the Oricon charts. In July 2008, their single "<a href="Love%20the%20World">Love the World</a>" debuted at number one, making it the first technopop song to reach number one in Oricon history. Other Japanese female technopop artists soon followed, including <a href="Mitsuki%20Aira">Aira Mitsuki</a>, <a href="immi">immi</a>, <a href="Masami%20Mitsuoka">Mizca</a>, <a href="SAWA">SAWA</a>, <a href="Saori%20at%20destiny">Saoriiiii</a>, and <a href="Sweet%20Vacation">Sweet Vacation</a>.
Anime music, image song and Vocaloid.
During the late 2000s and the early 2010s, the <a href="music%20in%20Japanese%20animation">anime music industry</a>, such as voice actors and <a href="image%20song">image song</a>s, added weight to Japanese music. Though anime music was formerly influenced by J-pop and "visual kei" music, Japanese indie music apparently influenced the genre at the 2006 <a href="FanimeCon">FanimeCon</a>. In 2007, after <a href="sampling%20%28music%29">sampling</a> voice actress <a href="Saki%20Fujita">Saki Fujita</a>'s voice to develop it, <a href="Vocaloid">Vocaloid</a> <a href="Hatsune%20Miku">Hatsune Miku</a> was released, and many songs featuring Hatsune Miku were shown on the <a href="Nico%20Nico%20Douga">Nico Nico Douga</a>. Some of the musicians featuring Hatsune Miku, such as <a href="Livetune">Livetune</a> and <a href="Supercell%20%28band%29">Supercell</a>, joined large record companies in Japan. Livetune released "Re: Package" on <a href="Victor%20Entertainment">Victor Entertainment</a> on August 27, 2008, and Supercell released "<a href="Supercell%20%28album%29">Supercell</a>" on <a href="Sony%20Music%20Entertainment%20Japan">Sony Music</a> on March 4, 2009. The albums "Re: Package" and "Supercell" were not brought under the control of the <a href="copyright">copyright</a> system of the <a href="Japanese%20Society%20for%20Rights%20of%20Authors%2C%20Composers%20and%20Publishers">Japanese Society for Rights of Authors, Composers and Publishers</a> (JASRAC), breaking the tradition that the musicians under the major labels affiliated with the system.
In June 2009, voice actress <a href="Nana%20Mizuki">Nana Mizuki</a>'s album "<a href="Ultimate%20Diamond">Ultimate Diamond</a>" became the first voice actor album to reach number one on the Oricon weekly charts. The fictional all female band Hōka-go Tea Time, from the anime series "<a href="K-On%21">K-On!</a>", released the mini-album "Hōka-go Tea Time" on July 22, 2009. The mini-album debuted at number one on the Oricon weekly album charts, becoming the first album by anime characters to reach number one. In May 2010, "Exit Tunes Presents Vocalogenesis feat. Hatsune Miku" became the first album featuring Vocaloids to reach number one on the Oricon weekly charts, replacing Hideaki Tokunaga's "Vocalist 4", which had topped the charts for four consecutive weeks.
2010s: Popularity of idol groups.
Since the end of the 2000s, more and more <a href="Japanese%20idol">idol groups</a> have emerged. The high number of idol groups in the Japanese entertainment industry is sometimes called the "Warring Idols Period" (アイドル戦国時代, a"idoru sengoku jidai"), an allusion to the <a href="Sengoku-jidai">Sengoku-jidai</a>. Some of the most successful groups during the 2010s include <a href="Hey%21%20Say%21%20JUMP">Hey! Say! JUMP</a>, <a href="AKB48">AKB48</a>, <a href="Arashi">Arashi</a>, <a href="Kanjani%20Eight">Kanjani Eight</a>, <a href="Morning%20Musume">Morning Musume</a>, and <a href="Momoiro%20Clover%20Z">Momoiro Clover Z</a>.
<a href="Kyary%20Pamyu%20Pamyu">Kyary Pamyu Pamyu</a>, a <a href="Harajuku">Harajuku-based</a> fashion model, made her musical debut in 2011 and gained international popularity with her debut single "<a href="Pon%20Pon%20Pon">Pon Pon Pon</a>", recognized by some Western celebrities such as <a href="Katy%20Perry">Katy Perry</a> and <a href="Ariana%20Grande">Ariana Grande</a>. She is produced by Yasutaka Nakata, who also produces the group Perfume. She subsequently gained success through her songs "<a href="Ninja%20Re%20Bang%20Bang">Ninja Re Bang Bang</a>" and "<a href="Fashion%20Monster">Fashion Monster</a>". During 2014, about 486,000 people attended <a href="Momoiro%20Clover%20Z">Momoiro Clover Z</a>'s live concerts, which was the highest recorded concert attendance for any female musician in Japan.
In 2019, AKB48 announced the postponement of its general election, and Arashi announced the group's hiatus.
Artists.
Some Japanese pop artists are extremely popular in Japan, and some also have fanbases in other countries—especially in Asia, but also in Western countries. They influence not only music, but also fashion. As of 2016, the top five best-selling artists in the Japanese <a href="Oricon">Oricon</a> charts history are <a href="B%27z">B'z</a>, <a href="Mr.%20Children">Mr. Children</a>, <a href="Ayumi%20Hamasaki">Ayumi Hamasaki</a>, <a href="Southern%20All%20Stars">Southern All Stars</a>, and <a href="Dreams%20Come%20True%20%28band%29">DREAMS COME TRUE</a>. Among the five, Hamasaki holds the record for being the only solo artist.
